abstract: As Bank of America trims away its asset-management businesses, one big question remains: What will it do with its 34 percent stake in BlackRock, the world’s largest money manager?
snippet: As Bank of America trims away its asset-management businesses, one big question remains: What will it do with its 34 percent stake in BlackRock, the world’s largest money manager?
lead_paragraph: As Bank of America trims away its asset-management businesses, one big question remains: What will it do with the 34 percent stake in BlackRock, the world’s largest money manager, that it inherited from Merrill Lynch?

headline.main: Bank of America Weighs Sale of BlackRock Stake

byline.original: By Michael J. de la Merced

abstract: General Motors has added Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Citigroup to the slate of its lead underwriters for its initial public offering, two sources familiar with the situation told Reuters on Friday.
snippet: General Motors has added Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Citigroup to the slate of its lead underwriters for its initial public offering, two sources familiar with the situation told Reuters on Friday.
lead_paragraph: General Motors has added Bank of America Merrill Lynch and Citigroup to the slate of its lead underwriters for its initial public offering, two people with lnowledge of the situation told Reuters on Friday.

headline.main: G.M. Said to Add Bank of America and Citigroup as Underwriters

abstract: A congressman wants to eliminate the dual roles played by big mortgage servicers, Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest column in The New York Times.
snippet: A congressman wants to eliminate the dual roles played by big mortgage servicers, Gretchen Morgenson writes in her latest column in The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: From Gretchen Morgenson’s latest column in The New York Times:

headline.main: Morgenson: In This Play, One Role Is Enough

abstract: Banks led by JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley stand to make a combined $120 million on General Motors’s initial public offering. If it weren’t for Goldman Sachs, they could have made four times as much.
snippet: Banks led by JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley stand to make a combined $120 million on General Motors’s initial public offering. If it weren’t for Goldman Sachs, they could have made four times as much.
lead_paragraph: 8:24 a.m. | Updated Wall Street banks led by JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley stand to make a combined $120 million on General Motors’s initial public offering. If it weren’t for Goldman Sachs, they could have made four times as much, Bloomberg news reported.

headline.main: Goldman Said to Cost Rivals Fees in G.M. Offering
